docs.lead_paragraph: Last week Standard and Poor's, a bond rating agency, downgraded both Ford and General Motors bonds to junk status. That is, it sees a significant risk that the companies won't be able to pay their debts.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column says workers in world's richest nation can no longer count on private sector to provide them with economic security; contrasts earnings and benefits of autoworkers in 1968 with those of Wal-Mart employees today; says question is whether public's desire for stronger safety net will finally be seconded by corporations that have not yet adopted Wal-Mart model of minimal benefits and always low wages (M)
docs.snippet: Why America's workers need the safety net.

docs.lead_paragraph: About 350 French surgeons have gone off for a week to Camber Sands, a beach resort in southeast England, to demand higher operating fees and to protest rising insurance premiums in France. French health care has long been the envy of the British, who complain of long waits to see a doctor and of poor hospital conditions. But the French surgeons, who plan to continue the protest until tomorrow, say those who provide lesser medical services, like radiologists, are often better paid. John Tagliabue (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: France: Surgeons Protest On The English Seaside

docs.snippet: About 350 French surgeons have gone off for a week to Camber Sands, a beach resort in southeast England, to demand higher operating fees and to protest rising insurance premiums in France. French health care has long been the envy of the British, who...

docs.lead_paragraph: Aegon NV, the Dutch insurer, said first-quarter profit rose 5 percent as gains on investments made up for a decline in insurance earnings. Net income rose to 666 million euros ($857 million), or 42 cents a share, from 633 million euros, or 41 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Profit from traditional life insurance fell 4 percent to 121 million euros. Earnings from fixed annuities fell 50 percent and profit from variable annuities dropped 26 percent. Quarterly profit from accident and health insurance rose 6 percent to 87 million euros. Aegon's gain on investments, which include equities, bonds and real estate, rose 57 percent to 302 million euros

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Insurer Posts Profit

docs.snippet: Aegon NV, the Dutch insurer, said first-quarter profit rose 5 percent as gains on investments made up for a decline in insurance earnings. Net income rose to 666 million euros ($857 million), or 42 cents a share, from 633 million euros, or 41 cents a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Molina Healthcare, which arranges health care services for Medicaid recipients, said it lost contracts with two California counties worth a combined $111 million in annual revenue. The California Department of Health Services will give the contracts for Riverside and San Bernardino Counties to another health care manager, Molina said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Molina said it expected a start-up operation in Indiana, higher interest income and the acquisition of about 70,000 members in San Diego to make up for the lost revenue. Molina said it planned to appeal the decision. The contracts, which cover 96,492 members, expire March 31, 2006.

headline.main: MOLINA HEALTHCARE LOSES TWO CONTRACTS IN CALIFORNIA

docs.snippet: Molina Healthcare, which arranges health care services for Medicaid recipients, said it lost contracts with two California counties worth a combined $111 million in annual revenue. The California Department of Health Services will give the contracts...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration will create an advisory panel to recommend big changes in Medicaid eligibility and benefits and in the financing of the program, administration officials said Wednesday. By Sept. 1, the panel is to recommend ways to save $10 billion in Medicaid, the federal-state program that insures more than 50 million low-income people.

headline.main: New Panel Will Study Medicaid With Eyes Toward Big Changes

docs.abstract: Bush administration will create advisory panel to recommend big changes in Medicaid eligibility, benefits and financing, to save $10 billion; Sec Michael O Leavitt, who will appoint voting members, rejects bipartisan Congressional pleas for independent commission under auspices of National Academy of Sciences (S)
docs.snippet: The Bush administration will create an advisory panel to recommend big changes in Medicaid eligibility and benefits and in the financing of the program.

docs.lead_paragraph: Three unions at United Airlines said on Wednesday that they were prepared to strike to protect their contracts, one day after the carrier, which is operating under bankruptcy protection, received court permission to terminate four pension plans. The unions -- representing flight attendants, bag handlers and machinists -- all issued statements saying members gave wide approval to strike. A spokeswoman for the Association of Flight Attendants, which has 21,000 members at United, said the union would most likely respond through unannounced and intermittent strikes called chaos strikes. Such actions could take the form of a one-day national strike or a strike on a single flight at a remote location.

headline.main: Unions Threaten to Strike After Pension Default at United

docs.abstract: Three unions at United Airlines says it is prepared to strike to protect their contracts, one day after carrier, which is operating under bankruptcy protection, received court permission to terminate four pension plans; unions--representing flight attendants, bag handlers and machinists--issue statements saying members give wide approval to strike; Association of Flight Attendants says union will most likely respond through unannounced and intermittent strikes called chaos strikes; such actions could take form of one-day national strike or strike on single flight at remote location; United says any strikes would be illegal because rest of workers' labor agreements remain in effect; UAL, parent company of United, says first-quarter loss more than doubled to $1.07 billion from loss of $459 million year earlier; sales rose less than 1 percent, to $3.92 billion from $3.91 billion; company has lost $5.8 billion since entering bankruptcy protection in December 2002; photo of IAM district president Randy Canale (M)
docs.snippet: CHICAGO, May 11 - Three unions at United Airlines said on Wednesday that they were prepared to strike to protect their contracts, one day after the carrier, which is operating under bankruptcy protection, received court permission to terminate four...

byline.original: By ALEXEI BARRIONUEVO; Micheline Maynard in Detroit contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Choosing Sides Over $9.68 an Hour'' (Business Day, May 4), the annual wage of a full-time Wal-Mart employee -- $17,600 -- was compared with the United States poverty line for a family of three ($15,219) and a family of four ($19,157). But it is widely agreed that our poverty thresholds are woefully out of date and no longer represent what working families need to make ends meet. Our research on what it costs such families to afford basic necessities yields values far higher than the poverty lines. For example, in Wal-Mart's hometown, Bentonville, Ark., safe yet modest housing alone costs $6,500 per year; adding in health insurance, child care and other necessities raises the budget for a family with a couple of children to over $30,000.

docs.lead_paragraph: The O'Brien family is preparing for another funeral. This one is for Michael O'Brien, who was vibrant and happy when he died at age 39 on May 1. His death was unlike that of his mother, Alice, and his sister Diane. They ebbed away, as the neurological disorder Huntington's disease laid waste to their personalities, intellect and bodies. Though he was healthy, in a sense the disease claimed Michael, too.

headline.main: A Family That Knows Loss Is Staggered by Latest Loss

docs.abstract: Michael O'Brien dies at age 39 while climbing Mount Everest; climb was to raise money to help find cure for Huntington's disease, neurological disorder that claimed lives of his mother and sister in Oswego, NY; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Michael O'Brien died while climbing Mount Everest to raise money to help find a cure for Huntington's disease, which has shadowed his family.

docs.lead_paragraph: Having now outlined the two biggest components of his approach to Social Security -- cutting benefits from promised levels for most workers and establishing investment accounts -- President Bush is trying to turn the focus to another aspect of the debate: where are the Democrats? The White House and its allies are increasingly prodding, imploring, mocking, daring and threatening Democrats in the hopes of forcing them to put on the table their ideas for dealing with the retirement system's projected long-term problems.

headline.main: Democrats Resist Bait on Social Security

docs.abstract: White House and its allies are prodding, imploring, mocking, daring and threatening Democrats in hopes of forcing them to put on table their ideas for dealing with Social Security's projected long-term problems; aim is to provide political cover for Pres Bush; so far, Democratic leaders in Congress refuse to play along, and there is little indication they will change their mind (Political Memo)(M)
docs.snippet: Having now outlined his approach to Social Security, President Bush is trying to turn the focus to another aspect of the debate: Where are the Democrats?

byline.original: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON; David E. Rosenbaum contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Governors and state legislators have devised proposals for sweeping changes in Medicaid to curb its rapid growth and save billions of dollars. Under the proposals, some beneficiaries would have to pay more for care, and states would have more latitude to limit the scope of services.

headline.main: STATES PROPOSING SWEEPING CHANGE TO TRIM MEDICAID

docs.abstract: Governors and state legislators, faced with rapid growth of Medicaid, devise proposals that would require some beneficiaries to pay more for care and give states more latitude to limit scope of services, in effort to save billions of dollars; Congress has just endorsed budget blueprint that would cut projected Medicaid spending by $10 billion over next five years; many state proposals resemble ideas advanced by Pres Bush in his 2006 budget; some state proposals go further than Bush's, but they reject any Bush recommendation that they believe would shift costs to states; coalition of beneficiary advocates, including AARP and Families USA, plus labor unions and health care providers is already gearing up to fight any significant cutbacks in Medicaid; state officials claim their goal is not just to save money, but to avoid wholesale cuts in coverage like those in Tennessee, which is dropping more than 300,000 people from its Nedicaid rolls, and Missouri, which is dropping 90,000; Medicaid program, originally intended for poor, now covers people with incomes well above poverty level in some states (M)
docs.snippet: The plans provide guidance to Congress, which endorsed a budget blueprint that would cut projected Medicaid spending by $10 billion over the next five years.
